name: 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccine
description: Find out about the 4-in-1 pre-school booster, including who should have it, how to get it and side effects.

hasPart.description: The 4-in-1 pre-school booster helps protect against serious illnesses such as polio and tetanus. It's given to children aged 3 years, 4 months old.

hasPart.headline: 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccine
hasPart.text: Who it's for

hasPart.headline: 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccine
hasPart.text: Contraindications

hasPart.headline: 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccine
hasPart.text: How to get it

hasPart.headline: 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccine
hasPart.text: Side effects
The 4-in-1 pre-school booster is given to children aged 3 years, 4 months old before they start school.
Most children can have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster. They cannot have it if they've had a serious allergic reaction to an ingredient in it.
Your GP surgery will usually contact you to arrange your child's 4-in-1 pre-school booster. Speak to your GP surgery if you have not been contacted.
Side effects of the 4-in-1 pre-school booster include swelling or pain where the injection was given, feeling tired and a high temperature.

hasPart.description: The 4-in-1 pre-school booster helps protect against diphtheria, polio, tetanus and whooping cough

hasPart.text:
The 4-in-1 pre-school booster helps protect children against 4 serious illnesses:

  • diphtheria
  • polio
  • tetanus
  • whooping cough

It boosts the protection provided by the 6-in-1 vaccine.

hasPart.headline: What the 4-in-1 pre-school booster is for

hasPart.description: The 4-in-1 pre-school booster is given to children aged 3 years, 4 months old before they start school.

hasPart.text:
The 4-in-1 pre-school booster is recommended for children aged 3 years, 4 months old before they start school.

They're given 1 dose of the vaccine as part of the NHS vaccination schedule.

If your child has missed their 4-in-1 pre-school booster, contact their GP surgery. It's best to have it on time, but they can still have the 4-in-1 vaccine up to the age of 10.

hasPart.headline: Who should have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster

hasPart.description: Most children can have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster. They cannot have it if they've had a serious allergic reaction to an ingredient in it.

hasPart.text:
Most children can have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster.

The only reasons your child cannot have the vaccine is if either:

  • they've had a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to a vaccine that protects against diphtheria, polio, tetanus or whooping cough (such as the 6-in-1 vaccine)
  • they've had a serious allergic reaction to anything in the vaccine (including neomycin, polymyxin or formaldehyde)

hasPart.headline: Information
hasPart.text:
Getting vaccinated if your child is unwell

Your child can have the 4-in-1 vaccine if they're unwell but they do not have a high temperature.

If your child has a high temperature, wait until they're feeling better before having the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Who cannot have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster

hasPart.description: You can check the ingredients in the 4-in-1 pre-school booster by asking to see the patient leaflet or searching for it online.

hasPart.text:
There are 2 types of 4-in-1 pre-school booster vaccines given in the UK. You can check the ingredients in the patient leaflets:

  • Boostrix IPV 4-in-1 vaccine patient leaflet (Electronic Medicines Compendium website; PDF only, 150KB)
  • Repevax 4-in-1 vaccine patient leaflet (Electronic Medicines Compendium website)

hasPart.headline: 4-in-1 pre-school booster ingredients

hasPart.description: Your GP surgery will usually contact you to arrange your child's 4-in-1 pre-school booster. Speak to your GP surgery if you have not been contacted.

hasPart.text:
Your GP surgery will usually contact you about your child's 4-in-1 pre-school booster. This will usually be by letter, text, phone call or email.

It's best to have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster on time, but children can still have it up to the age of 10.

hasPart.headline: Speak to your GP surgery if:
hasPart.text:
• you have not been contacted to get your child's 4-in-1 pre-school booster
  • your child has missed their 4-in-1 pre-school booster
  • your child is unwell and is due to have the 4-in-1 pre-school booster – they may need to wait until they're feeling better before having the vaccine
  • you need to change a vaccination appointment

Your GP surgery can book or rearrange an appointment.

hasPart.headline: How to get the 4-in-1 pre-school booster

hasPart.description: Side effects of the 4-in-1 pre-school booster include swelling or pain where the injection was given, feeling tired and a high temperature.

hasPart.text:
Most of the side effects of the 4-in-1 pre-school booster are mild and usually get better within a few days.

They can include:

  • swelling or pain where the injection was given
  • feeling tired or irritable
  • a high temperature
  • a headache

A hard lump may appear where the vaccine was given, but this will usually go after a few weeks.

More serious side effects such as a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) are very rare. The person who vaccinates your child will be trained to deal with allergic reactions and treat them immediately.

hasPart.headline: Side effects of the 4-in-1 pre-school booster
